bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, June 16, 1920

div1.p: Carter writes about Gorgas and his own health. He is currently in Havana, Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Laura Armistead Carter, June 16, 1920

opener.dateline:
UNITED FRUIT COMPANY
STEAMSHIP SERVICE
Habana
June16/20

div1.p:
I sent your other letter
Ashore this morning. Had I
known, I had saved a day
because the P Key West
S. S. leaves at 10 A. M. & I
could have taken it over
to her & it had gone off
this morning instead of
tomorrow- A day's delay
makes
2
no difference about your letter, but it may make a dif-
ference in Lyster's paper - as he may send it on for pub-
lication before he gets the corrections, for which he, at
least, should be sorry:

(1) I see in the paper today - that poor Gorgas has had a stroke
of apoplexy & has had to give up the African work. In
I am grievously sorry for him. Frankly I don't think he was in
a proper condition to do his best - and it is the truth - good
work when I last saw him. I wish he had talked over his
plans, with me or with anyone competent to discuss them.
I mean his general plans & the detail of carrying them out
When I saw him at Payta - only for an hour & a half it is true
- he
3
he had no plans for Peru.
Of course he was tired & I presume
feeling badly from the sea - al
though it was dead smooth &
the Huasco is a large ship -
yet he evidently had not
formulated any plan - gen
eral or in detail. A clearly for-
#
mulated plan of action - sub-
ject to change of course - is to
my mind essential in any
large undertaking - especially
for
4
for old men who are less ready
than they were.

(2) Guiteras left 14 days ago &
- has not been heard from since

(3) I went to see Frank Menocal
- in charge of Maritime Q. - &
found him very glad to see
me. We are going tomor-
row to look over his Q. station
- at Triscenia & afterward
have dinn breakfast to-
gether - with Havard - cat
3)-
Colonel Havard
5
Colonel Havard - a retired offi-
cer of the U.S. Med Med-
Corps. who was chief surgeon
of the Island of Cuba in 1900.
& my very good friend. We
roomed in the same house
- we two only in “Chaffee's Pal-
ace” - which had 16 bed rooms.
& for which the U.S. Paid $6000
for annum rent. He is
Med. Inspector General of
the Cuban Army now.
6
or
He retired in 1907 - but
came back in service du-
ring the war. A. French-
man - from South France - as
indeed are all the “ards
- “Ards” - (Brevard: Bayard:
Archivard etc). Refugeed after
the Franco-Prussian war &
entered the U.S. Army- I's
Was a Prof. of Botany- Is
about 77 or 8 years old.
A great Botanist - which
was
7
was our first bond of Union.

I didn't see him today - as
he was sick- If he he still
sick todaymorrow I will go out
to see him: I know where he
lives- I think I will also call
on Mrs Guiteras - whom I have
never met - although I am
told she sees no one. She is
at Las Animas Hospital
- where they have quarters-
If she can't - or won't see me
well
8
8
Well but if she would & I did
not call it now might hurt
Guiteras.

3) Another thing & one of which
you will approve- I took
breakfast - by myself - at the
Dos Hermanos, & “blew my-
self”- Langustinos (broiled)
Arroz con pollio: & for postres
Jalea de Guayaba y Queso-
Crema del Norte - & a cup of
black coffee which was simply
9
delicious. It had been much
better with a glass of Rioga
UNITED FRUIT COMPANY
STEAMSHIP SERVICE
Clarete - but I feel bound to
drink nothing while I am in
the service - to July 20 - at any
rate. Still it was the most
satisfactory meal I have had
for a long time - delicious
Spanish head.

Later
Drs Torralbos & Sanchez Agra-
monte came out to the S. S.
to Call - both were in my service
in
10
1899- All three of my old
clerks are still employed
here - one, Condé, in the U.S.P.
H.S. office & the other two, de
Soto. & Espinosa in the Im-
migration - all knew me.
& were apparently very glad
to see me. This witnesseth;

(2) That there can have been
little change for political
reasons in the Sanitary De-
partment

(3) That the Cubans who go in
as clerks have little either
little ambition & initia-
tive or else little chance to
rise, for Espinosa & de Soto.
date from /99 & Condé from
1900.

I will could not find any
testament in any of the
3 book stores I tried- Better
luck tomorrow-

div1.p:
I took dinnerbreakfast with Dr
Menocal yesterday & din-
ner with Dr Wilson - of San-
tiago- The two were too much
for me & I am feeling “bum”
this morning. Took no wine
& did not eat much either,
probably too much coffee.

Saw - at his request - General
Mario Menocal, the President,
& had an interesting talk
with him.

Also went out - with Havard
& called on Mrs Guiteras
at Las Animas, Hospital.
To my surprise she rec'd
me & we had quite a talk
- she speaks no English - main-
ly about you & her dead
daughter, Miss Guiteras
- his sister - came in later
& she talked of your book - Gui-
teras has evidently told them
much of you: I am re-
turning to Las Animas
this morning to see what
Lchedo has to show me
of the Leptospira icteroi-
des: but - I am not go-
ing to take dinner ashore
with anyone, I will have
take breakfast- I am afraid
of the return of my trunk
“Kink” trouble.

I think the enclosed dates
came
came from Dr (Francisco)
Menocal.

I may have a chance to
write tonight - we leave
tomorrow at 8 A.M. but I
doubt it
